key_title: Key to the species of Styphelia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Ericaceae

source.author: Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Epacridaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Albrecht, D.E. (1996). Epacridaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Axillary inflorescences all or mostly single-flowered (rarely some 2- or 3-flowered) with subtending bracts and bracteoles collectively more than 3; bracts and bracteoles often difficult to distinguish from one another and grading in size to the sepals
Axillary inflorescences single-flowered, spicate or racemose, individual flowers subtended by a solitary persistent or caducous (sometimes leaf-like) bract and two bracteoles
Staminal filaments broad and distinctly flattened, ± fleshy; stamens not or barely exserted from corolla tube; corolla red or orange
Staminal filaments slender, terete to slightly flattened; stamens distinctly exserted beyond corolla tube; corolla white, yellow or pinkish
Prostrate or decumbent shrub; leaves 8–32 mm long; sepals 7–13.5 mm long; corolla tube 12.5–20 mm long, the interior surface with a ring of hairs towards the base; Grampians to eastern Victoria
Erect shrub; leaves 3.2–9 mm long; sepals 2.4–3.2 mm long; corolla tube 3–4.3 mm long, the interior surface glabrous in the lower half; Big Desert
Leaves distinctly concave on upper surface
Leaves flat or convex
Leaves obovate to ovate or suborbicular; obtuse at apex (but sometimes shortly mucronate); western
Leaves narrow, tapered at base, acute (rarely obtuse) and often pointed at apex; eastern, except widespread L. ericoides
Leaves tapered at base; flowers pendent
Leaves truncate to cordate at base; flowers erect
Leaves ovate to broadly ovate, less than 2 mm wide, lower surface with very short hairs between veins; flowers normally solitary (sometimes paired)
Leaves broadly ovate to orbicular, 3–12 mm wide, wider than long, both surfaces glabrous; flowers normally paired (sometimes solitary or in 3s)
Leaves erect, flat, sometimes slightly twisted, mostly longer than 15 mm; ovary 2-locular; localized on poorly drained, near-coastal heaths in the far east
Leaves spreading to ascending, usually distinctly convex (if leaves ever flat then habitat not as above), rarely to 15 mm long
Flowers solitary or paired (rarely in clusters of 3)
Flowers several in short, erect axillary spikes
Corolla lobes up to half as long as tube; corolla tube clearly exceeding sepals
Corolla lobes subequal to or distinctly longer than tube; corolla tube not exceeding sepals
Corolla tube 2.5–4.5 mm long; lobes about half as long as tube; trailing to decumbent shrub
Corolla tube 5–7 mm long; lobes only about one-quarter as long as tube; erect shrub
Flowers erect; style only 0.5–0.9 mm long, not reaching throat of corolla tube
Flowers pendent; style 4–7 mm long, exceeding throat of corolla tube
Leaves dull, usually roughened or variously hairy, margins strongly recurved to revolute; usually on sandy soils
Leaves smooth and shining above, glabrous, margins rather weakly recurved; apparently confined to gorge tracts of Snowy River
